fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad containers. It is cartesian iff P\ \iota \cong 1 and \text {pr} is an isomorphism. This is equivalent to saying that the extension of the monad container is a cartesian monad (container functors always preserve pullbacks).
These can also be seen as proper (1,\Sigma ) type universes (Tarski-style).

fr:title.text: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Possible extra conditions for monad containers

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These are mostly inspired by Zwart and Marsden's research into no-go theorems for distributive laws between algebraic theories [zwartmarsden2022].

I've been roughly translating properties of algebraic theories into the language of monad containers (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}), by considering:
Shapes s : S as "terms"
Positions p : P\ s as "free variables in the term s"
\iota as a "generic variable placeholder"
\sigma as a "generalised substitution"
\text {pr} as a "reindexing" of positions after a "substitution" This is not meant to be an exact translation; the idea is to get inspiration for properties of monad containers we might want to consider when proving things about monad container distributive laws.
(S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) satisfies the singleton property if P\ \iota \cong 1. All cartesian monad containers have this property by definition.

A property of algebraic theories that is used implicitly in [zwartmarsden2022] is commutativity of disjoint substitutions, i.e. given terms s, s_0 and a substitution f where for all y, x 
otin 	ext {var}(f(y)) we always have that: s[s_0/x][f(y) / y 
eq x] = s[f(y) / y 
eq x][s_0/x]

The List monad container \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} satisfies this, which makes sense since it can also be represented by an algebraic theory. This also holds for coproduct, reader (trivially), state, writer, and probably many others!
EDIT: In fact, this holds for all monad containers, and the proof is quite simple (just use associativity of \sigma and "pull the case distinctions through the inner \sigma ").
(S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) has a constant shape if there exists some s_0 : S where P\ s_0 \cong 0.

Notice that all functions P\ s_0 \to S are equal to \lambda \_ . \iota , since P\ s_0 is propositional and pointed (and therefore contractible). As a consequence of this, we have that: \sigma \ s_0\ f = \sigma \ s_0\ (\lambda \_ . \iota ) = s_0

This holds for \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} for example: take n to be any natural number greater than 0, take f := \lambda \_ . 0, and then given some x : \text {Fin}\ n we have \sum _{i = 0}^{n} f^x\ i = 1. Notice that this property holds for all n with non-empty position sets, so \mathbb {N} \triangleleft \text {Fin} actually satisfies a stronger condition (analogous to Zwart and Marsden's S4 [zwartmarsden2022]).
This also holds for state, by taking s = \text {id} and f = \lambda \_ . \text {id}.

EDIT (12/12/24): I realised that I was missing the associativity equation for the definition of the algebraic theory for a finitary cartesian monad container, and in the process realised that finitary cartesian monad containers are exactly non-symmetric operads!

To show this, consider (S \triangleleft P, \iota , \sigma ). The set (or type) of operations for each n : \mathbb {N} is given by n \mapsto \sum _{s : S} |\negthinspace | P\ s \cong n |\negthinspace | where \iota is the identity operation, and \sigma is composition. All operations have finite arity by the finitary assumption on the monad container.

That monad containers were generalisations of non-symmetric operads (in this way) was already noticed by Tarmo Uustalu in [uustalu2017], but an explicit construction showing how they can be recovered was not given. Based on the rest of this post, I believe that Tarmo's generalisation of the list monad container in terms of any non-symmetric operad characterises exactly the cartesian monad containers that correspond to algebraic theories.
